body:
Facebook makes money from ads. They make money from having users

Google makes money from ads. They make money from having users. 

Microsoft makes money from milking corporations for Windows Enterprise / Server / Cloud / Office 365. A strong user base familiar with Microsoft products are more willing to work with Microsoft once they advance into senior roles in their company. They almost feel like they're getting free stuff, in reality they're victoms of vendor lock in. 

Zoom loses money from having users. They're effectively leaches untill they turn into paying customers. Most potential consumers already have alternatives they don't have to pay for or already have access to.

author: Casandy420
body:
Maybe, but I think it might take longer than most people think. Tech firms sell to governments. Microsoft is one of the largest military contractors around the world. Pretty much every country's military runs windows.

Just listened to the q3 earnings call. Cloud demand is up like crazy right now. So, money is being shifted away from local resources into cloud computing resources. So many of AWS and Azure customers are shifting money into these tech companies. Smaller firms like NetApp, Atlassian, or Slack are seeing sales raise with this new demand.

&#x200B;

Also, there are entirely new markets for tech that weren't viable pre covid. Consider the NFL, NBA....I can't remember the sport, but they now use MSTeams. Companies are seeing the cost benefits of remote work. Virtual Formula 1 is another example. Things are going to be interesting. To stay competitive, you will need to piviot into this new economic situation. Red Robin is an interesting case study. They cut costs like crazy and embraced off site orders. Or look at Trupanion's 10K. They cut costs and increased cash on hand to a point where they can operate for an entire year w/o income.

&#x200B;

You have to remember that there are millions of dollars worth of human intelligence driving the decisions behind each of these Tickers. Boards are made up of people with way way way way more industry knowledge than anyone on reddit. Yes, Tesla exists, and a tweet can swing billions of dollars around the moon, but for the most part, companies are ran by intelligent folks trying their best to make money. That's it. Even if the world is on fire, these people will find a way to sell you insurance on credit. The economy has existed since before the old testament. Exodus 30:11-16  is just ancient hebrew tax law. Even if it's not money, people will find something to trade to create value. The wheel keeps on turning.

EDIT: Totally forgot, look at MSFT 10K. B2B OEM sales are the bread and butter. So you will need to see large retailers (including amazon) collapse before companies like intel and MSFT will feel the big hits.

author: nckmiz
body:
The market was down 30% for a week or so. You think Berk can just deploy 60 billion the way you deploy 5k? He’s not going to go buy more than a few billion in shares of Apple/MSFT, etc. with that money. He doesn’t ever want to hold over 10% positions in publicly traded companies for disclosure reasons. His game at this size is waiting for attractive companies to be in need. What company that was attractive in late March was in desperate need of capital? How quickly do you think Berk can negotiate a full on takeover? 

He’s in a waiting game. This thing is far from over. He’s not a hedge fund manager buying temporary market dips.

author: xPURE_AcIDx
body:
From my experience it seems like Teams is winning this battle. My company just switched from zoom to Teams. My Oil&gas clients all use Teams. 

I have only witnessed mass use of zoom through free users, and universities. Universities which have access to both Microsoft and Google products. I'd imagine if this covid stuff pushes into fall these companies will get universities to use their products already bundled with suite of products. Instead of paying for an additional product. Considering that university virtual classes have suffered from trolls, using a product like hangouts that would require your university email will secure these chats. 

I hold no Microsoft/Google shares, and I have no stakes in zoom's success or failures. Just food for thought.

Regardless, its a VERY good thing for investors because usually they make out quite well in the deal.

author: Singleguywithacat
body:
This earning season's reminds me of my first few parties in college.  I was super-excited, had all of the right clothes to wear, and was definitely looking forward to flossing the new-and-improved me.  The first party was definitely cool, as I felt my way around, filled with nervousness and anticipation.  I laughed off the fact I didn't actually go home with a woman that first night, or even get a number, or even talk to a woman, but I had a nice buzz and was prepared for my next shot.   It was kind of like my bet on Dominoes this earning's season, in hindsight it didn't work out, but I had done the research and looked forward to the next round.

The next few parties in college, I began to resent how easy it seemed to be for everybody else to have a good time, and get apparently what I was looking for.  I was beginning to get less and less optimistic, and that initial sense of euphoria and confidence was slowly turning into self-loathing and the feeling of petulance of not belonging there.  As I bet AMZN and MSFT this earnings season, the same feeling became me.  Why didn't I just click on FB instead, why did I blow $1600 on an expiring weekend SPY Put.  None of it makes sense, to anybody.  

Eventually at the end of my freshman year, I realized that parties weren't for me, and maybe I'm just a weirdo.  Maybe earnings aren't for me either, but I could just be broke.  In either event, I have no business being there or here.

author: SwanArmy
body:
I'm gonna drastically simplify this for you, keep in mind that this isn't the actual definition of IV by any means.

Essentially, Implied Volatility is an options term for how much the underlying stock will move in a given time frame. Since TSLA has much wider swings in stock price than say...AAPL or MSFT, TSLA has higher IV. This higher IV correlates to lower movement in options prices for large moves. For example, a 5% move in TSLA will result in 50-60% gains in TSLA at-the-money options, but a 5% move in MSFT will translate to 150-200% gains in MSFT at-the-money options.

TSLA is expected to move let's say....5 percent per day. It's NOT expected to move 5% in an hour. That's what i meant in that in general, TSLA's stock price was moving a lot more than expected (on high volume) during that timeframe.

author: ale632007
body:
Here is the patent [https://patents.google.com/patent/US20180292654A1/en?q=Scanner-illuminated+LCOS](https://patents.google.com/patent/US20180292654A1/en?q=Scanner-illuminated+LCOS) owned by Microsoft and it is citing [https://patents.google.com/patent/US8837050B2/en?q=Scanner-illuminated+LCOS](https://patents.google.com/patent/US8837050B2/en?q=Scanner-illuminated+LCOS) which belongs to MVIS. 

Seems that Joshua M. Hudman (inventor of US8837050B2) went from MVIS to Microsoft around the time this patent was filled, 2011, but now he is at Valve (relevant? meh) The patent that got approved today, was filled on 2017 by MS and that is the only link I found, didn’t care to dig in more, so make of it what you will. To me it means nothing that a patent was approved, always takes a while for them to get approved AFAIK.

author: DARPA1191969v1
body:
I can give the perspective from a tech/software dev.

In my opinion, these are sort of different players. In fact, I would say that NVDA and AMD are far more analogous to each other than even AMD -> AAPL, and certainly to MSFT. The  way that I see it, NVDA/AMD are fundamentally companies that are concerned with producing a *physical good* \- literal chipsets and dies. AAPL seems to waver on the hardware side of things (they have been known to go proprietary in that arena, but have also loaned out work to INTC on more than one occasion). I most certainly see MSFT as a true software/PaaS/SaaS company - suffice to say that they are producing very little in the way of physical goods.

I think the *soft/hardware* direction is important to mention, because that fundamentally plays into the way that these companies deal in the market. Developing hardware is a mind-bendingly expensive process (relatively speaking). It takes years of R&D and cash on hand to fund something that is truly great. An example of this would be the move AMD made to Zen (which is based on the concept of 'chiplets'; highly-scalable many-core designs that are fundamentally different from their monolithic predecessors).

In terms of growth, I would have to say that I see two viable options here: *NVDA and MSFT*. MSFT is pretty easy to explain; they create a product that fundamentally has lower upstart costs (software development's most expensive attribute is the cost of human labor) and lower maintenance costs (I would think). There is some movement towards a more data-center driven profit scheme (which would require boots on ground hardware en masse), and Azure is certainly an AWS competitor, but I think we've yet to see them really go full throttle on that (I think it could be big if they did).

NVDA is a leader from a technological perspective. GPU compute-cores are very specialized devices that are good at doing only a few things, but very, *very well.* NVDA has been hammering away at this technology for years - they know the game, and they know where the money is. Autonomous cars, drones...the computer viz recogition software for postal, for literally anything, runs on a platform that is fundamentally a GPU (very high level view here). Machine learning applications in this field at the data-center level (think machine learning on AWS) are absolutely dominated by NVDA; In fact I would go as far as to say there aren't really a lot of competitors out there that are bringing to the table what NVDA does (Honestly AMD has severely gimped even their consumer dies at this point).

&#x200B;

I can elaborate more, but I'd go with MSFT and NVDA on this one.

author: RawInquisitor
body:
Positions:
1. TSLA 805C/810C debit spread, 760P/765P debit spread.
Got each spread for 2$ (8000$ worth) 30 mins before earnings release. TSLA usually has a big swing in one direction. I have always lost money on TSLA, so didn't want to take much risk here. Should have sold the call spread when it was at 850 but yeah well. Sold the put spread today for a slight profit. Phew. 
2. QCOM 79C/78P at 3.5$ (3500$ worth). QCOM was trading at 78.5 so I felt like this was a no brainer given that both QCOM and AAPL have their earnings (AAPL earnings usually affect QCOM). Both my options were down yesterday. But AAPL earnings pushed QCOM down and the 78P was ITM. Sold it at a slight loss.

author: HallucinatoryFrog
body:
Great choice.  Nokia was having so many issues with their 5G rollout that they had to bring in Marvell to make their chips.

[https://www.lightreading.com/5g/nokia-hires-marvell-to-fix-5g-problems/d/d-id/757984](https://www.lightreading.com/5g/nokia-hires-marvell-to-fix-5g-problems/d/d-id/757984)

I am long on T, VZ, TMUS, QCOM, ABB, BB, MSFT, AMZN, TSLA, TSM, AMAT, ERIC for 5G.

Nokia might be a player in the 5G world, but they are currently in the worst shape of all of those stocks I just mentioned and keep messing up to the point that I'm not even sure I would see much return by investing in them.  Some of the biggest returns won't even be from the infrastructure, but the companies who will take advantage of the network to improve automation, autonomous driving, and all of the semiconductors, processors, and sensors that will power all of these innovations.

author: turello9
body: Qualcomm, Skyworks are good bets

author: savi9876
body:
I would think there’s gonna be 2 big camps, Huawei and anti-Huawei. 

So countries/companies going the anti-Huawei route will do Nokia and Ericsson. 

Is there really much info right now to differentiate Nokia & Ericsson ? 

Do we really know much about 5G in general, it’s so early. 

For the smartphone side rather than infrastructure it seems Qualcomm has a monopoly.

author: SorrowsSkills
body:
> DKNG or PENN as online sports betting becomes commonplace 

Are there any studies/statistics to show how fast this industry is growing? I'd love to educate myself in it. I've been looking into ERI, MGM, BOYD and Penn already but never really gave any attention to DKNG, Penns also probably been on the bottom of my list as well for gambling stocks, but I can definitely see the room for growth in online gambling via a phone in the future. 

&#x200B;

>Looking for companies working 5G infrastructure as it pertains to cloud computing, as I think the future of consumer networks is wireless, with only larger commercial pipes needing to be hard

I've been trying to find a good 5g play as well. Right now I'm looking into qualcomm and MU.

> I think Azure will win the cloud war for the majority of government and large caps so also looking for companies on the forward development side of that, especially in business intelligence, how it's used, etc. 

Another industry I know nothing about haha. I'm looking to get into microsoft if we see another dip and I'm already invested in Amazon which is currently the leader in cloud. I know microsoft is much better at marketing their products to big caps though which will further their revenues a lot. From what I read earlier (on reddit to be fair..) is that as of right now Amazon undeniably has the better cloud services (apparently microsoft is slightly lacking in their quality) but microsoft has been making up for this with their hard line  marketing towards big caps so I can see that being beneficial for them too. I think everything cloud is going to be big in general, so investing in anyone doing cloud is a good investment in the long run probably. 

I'm also invested in Alibaba which is investing HEAVILY into their cloud service and will probably be the biggest cloud service in China and likely surrounding nations within their sphere of influence so I definitely think they're great as well.
